If it was in the rosdep database you could install it using pip (rosdep can install packages from various package managers, both apt and pip are supported on Linux). But to release a package as a deb, all its dependencies need to be available via APT so we encourage people to not use pip dependencies.


As this module is almost unused in this package (at least in this PR), I would recommend getting rid of the dependency completely.
From what I can see there is only one function used from this module: `imutils.is_cv2()`. This is [just checking](https://github.com/jrosebr1/imutils/blob/9951937054188a4a2866ba70d296eff89179b82f/imutils/convenience.py#L154) if we are using OpenCV2 or OpenCV3.
As this package is targeting kinetic, we [already know](https://github.com/ros-perception/vision_opencv/blob/kinetic/cv_bridge/package.xml#L29) that we are using OpenCV3. If the goal is to be able  to support all ROS distros (including indigo that uses openCV2), we can use the fact that OpenCV is already imported line 17, and just check the value of `cv2.__version__` would give the answer (or `cv2.__version__[0]` if we just want to know the major). So importing a different module from pip just to do so seems a bit overkill.
